channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Lawmakers Want to Investigate Gorbachev
item.description: Five members of the Russian Parliament have asked the prosecutor general to open a criminal case to investigate the breakup of the Soviet Union and the role played by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: During Hagel Visit, China Showed Its Military Might, and Its Frustrations
item.description: During his official visit to China, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel encountered combative public warnings and private complaints that Beijing felt besieged by hostile neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: After visiting China this week, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel met with Mongolia’s defense minister, Bat-Erdene Dashdemberel, in Ulan Bator on Thursday.

item.title: Surprise in Race for India’s Premier: A Wife, of Sorts
item.description: Narendra Modi has stressed the advantages of his bachelorhood, but now he has acknowledged an arranged marriage some 45 years ago.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Supporters of the Bharatiya Janata Party held masks of Narendra Modi during a party rally on Thursday in Siliguri, India.

item.title: The Lede: Artists Try to Prick Conscience of Drone Operators With Giant Portrait of Orphan in Pakistani Field
item.description: A campaign started this week, “Not a Bug Splat,” sought to draw attention to the human cost of American drone strikes in Pakistan, and to communicate directly with the pilots who guide the bombers to their targets by remote control.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A new art installation unveiled in Pakistan this week features a huge image of a child reportedly orphaned in a drone strike in 2009.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Seeking More From Chinese Films
item.description: A jury at the China Film Directors’ Guild awards refused to award the two top prizes — for film and director of the year — saying that Chinese films need to meet “a higher standard.”
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The actress Zhao Tao in a scene from Jia Zhangke's film "A Touch of Sin," which has been barred from release in China.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Find Support, and Frustration, in Jordan
item.description: Jordan has been quietly providing a staging ground for the rebels and their foreign backers on Syria’s southern front, but many say the aid is not enough.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The situation is good: Jordan controls the border and arms are not brought in randomly,” said Bashar al-Zoabi, the head of the Yarmouk Division, a rebel group.

item.title: Banned Group’s Leader Given Pakistani Parliament Seat After Vote Dispute
item.description: A parliamentary seat has been granted to the head of a sectarian group that has long been accused of inciting violence against minority Shiites.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Bits Blog: Microsoft Touts Data Protection Approval in Europe; Eager for New Customers
item.description: The company’s top lawyer said its cloud computing services had met Europe’s stringent data protection rules, and he used the news as a way to woo potential new customers.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Bradford L. Smith, Microsoft's general counsel, right, with the company's former chief executive last year. “For customers who care about privacy and compliance, there is no more committed partner than Microsoft," Mr. Smith said.

item.title: Hoping for Asylum, Migrants Strain U.S. Border
item.description: Those who risk a danger-filled journey across Mexico to cross the Rio Grande into Texas are now primarily from Central America.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: Smugglers sent migrants across the Rio Grande at a point where the water is too shallow for Border Patrol boats that might have turned them back safely at the midriver boundary between the United States and Mexico.

item.title: Dogged Prosecutor Seeks to Paint Pistorius as a Bully
item.description: The South African athlete Oscar Pistorius, accused of killing his girlfriend, faced new questions from the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, about his relationship and his experiences firing guns.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius, center right, left the court in Pretoria, South Africa, where he is on trial.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 10
item.description: Rahul Gandhi, leader of the Congress party’s election campaign, cast his vote in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, left, vice-president of the Congress party, showing his inked finger after casting his vote in New Delhi.

item.title: European Union Debates Initiative on Embryo Protection
item.description: A hearing was held on a petition bearing 1.8 million signatures that would ban the use of European funds for activities such as stem-cell research.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Letter From Europe: Colonialism, Bloodshed and Blame for Rwanda
item.description: With the 20th anniversary of Rwanda's genocide and the centennial of the start of World War I, the time is ripe to explore the impact of colonialism.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Evidence Comes Up Short As Egypt Tries 3 Journalists
item.description: A courtroom was shown family photographs and video of trotting horses, but not the supposedly fabricated news videos that underlie the charges.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: India Ink: In Villages Torn by Violence, Traditional Loyalties at Risk
item.description: Hindus in the Muzaffarnagar district of Uttar Pradesh said that they had voted for the Bharatiya Janata Party, in many cases for the first time.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Sakur Ahmed, of Fugana village, showing his inked finger after casting his vote on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. to Send Peacekeepers to Central African Republic
item.description: The Security Council passed a resolution authorizing 12,000 peacekeepers to do whatever was necessary to protect civilians in the fractured country.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Deadly Blast at Fruit Market Shatters Calm in Pakistan’s Capital
item.description: The death toll is expected to rise in the Islamabad attack, which came while the Taliban, which denied any role in the blast, were in talks with the government.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistani men comforted one another on Wednesday after a bombing in Islamabad killed at least 22 people and injured 100.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Students End Occupation of Taiwan’s Legislature
item.description: Their departure concludes the most dramatic confrontation over ratification of a trade agreement with China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Student protesters carrying the sunflowers that symbolize their movement for government transparency walked out of the legislature building after they ended their occupation.

item.title: Sonar Finds Another Clue on Location of Missing Malaysian Jet
item.description: A possible acoustic signal the Indian Ocean will have to be analyzed further, but the source appeared to be man-made, the Australian authorities conducting the search said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A version of this torpedolike, sonar-equipped vehicle, made by Bluefin Robotics of Quincy, Mass., may be used to search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 if signals turn out to be authentic.

item.title: Greece Trumpets Return to International Bond Market
item.description: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Finance Minister Yannis Stournaras described the move as “a catalytic undertaking,” adding that Greece had made “the biggest fiscal adjustment ever recorded since World War II.”

item.title: In Eastern Ukraine, a One-Building, Pro-Russia Realm Persists Despite Criticism
item.description: A group of protesters who have seized the government headquarters in Donetsk, Ukraine, was urged by local politicians to give up and hand over its weapons.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A version of the flag of the Donetsk People’s Republic hung in an occupied government building.

item.title: India Ink: All Eyes on Delhi As It Goes To Vote
item.description: The three-way race for the capital’s seven parliamentary seats could be a bellwether of the national elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A woman cast her vote with her child during parliamentary elections on Thursday in New Delhi.

item.title: India Ink: How the Aam Aadmi Party Lost Its Way
item.description: After a surprising victory in the Delhi State elections, a series of strategic mistakes have arrested what at one point seemed the party’s irresistible momentum.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, center, Aam Aadmi Party's official candidate from the Varanasi parliamentary constituency, with supporters on the banks of River Ganges in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, on March 25.

item.title: In Mongolia, a Gift Horse for Hagel
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel named the horse Shamrock, but the traditional gift from Mongolia to American officials typically does not make its way back to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Mongolia’s minister of defense, Bat-Erdene Dashdemberel, left, presented U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel with a horse as a gift on Thursday.

item.title: Bomb Explodes Outside Greek Central Bank
item.description: No one was hurt in the explosion in Athens, which took place hours before Greece was to start issuing long-term bonds for the first time since 2010.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Police gathered evidence at the site of an explosion in Athens on Thursday.
